data.title: Don't ask me if I want to reload a file, especially if I haven't made any changes
data.body:
Can't seem to find the relevant code, but as of version 0.48.0, this dialog started popping up:

![screen shot 2014-01-31 at 11 53 11 am](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/282759/2052521/43c94d02-8a98-11e3-9fb1-0a08760e30b8.png)

Imagine this not-unlikely scenario:
1. Open up a bunch of files
2. Make some changes
3. Commit, push, pull request
4. Change branches

I then have to click "reload" for each open file, even those with no changes since the last save.

Not sure if it's a bug or if there's rationale (cool if so), but here's what I'd expect: if the file's changed on disk and I haven't touched it in Atom, just reload the thing. If something's changed, perhaps prompt me when I focus on that tab to prevent confirmation bombardment.

data.title: Recreate template ~/.atom files when opened and non-existent
data.body:
If something goes to `Open Your Keymap` and the file does not exist because they accidentally deleted it, it should recreate the file with the sample content.

Open it just as a blank editor prevents the person from reading the docs in the template file and seeing an exapmle.

data.title: Rename user.coffee to startup.coffee
data.body: Or possibly just remove support for it, either way `user.coffee` does not fit in with the naming scheme of other files in the `~/.atom` folder.

data.title: Rename ~/.atom/user.css to ~/.atom/styles.css
data.body:
Matches naming scheme of `keymap.cson`, `snippets.cson`, `config.cson`.

Fixes #1471

data.title: Fix whacky soft-wrap issues
data.body:
This PR adds:
1. An editor spec that randomly mutates a buffer and toggles soft wrap on and off, then compares the screen lines to a simple reference implementation to ensure everything stays in a correct state.
2. A new and radically simpler implementation of `RowMap` that eliminates all observed failures in the randomized test.

I feel pretty good about this now. The `RowMap` is way simpler now and I can't manage to get any of the failures I was previously driving out with the random spec. It's up to you guys whether you want to merge it while I'm gone. I think it might be worth it. I packaged it as a single commit so you can revert it if unexpected behaviors start cropping up.

It's worth noting that I added a dev dependency for an npm I'm using in the random spec. I'm not actually sure that's a thing. @kevinsawicki perhaps you can make an adjustment if necessary?

http://coffeescript.org/#changelog

data.title: Replace `atom` module with multiple built-in modules
data.body: Just like node provides built-in modules such as `fs` and `path`, Atom should provide built-in modules that can be referenced by name, such as `point`, `range`, and `editor-view`. We currently export these kinds of built-ins from a single `atom` module, but it might be less confusing to just document built-in modules.

data.title: ~/.atom/snippets.cson support
data.body:
- [x] Include `snippets.cson` instead of a snippets folder in the template `.atom` folder
- [x] Add _Open Your Snippets_ menu item
- [x] Upgrade snippets package

Fixes atom/snippets#6

What's left:

data.title: Update atom-shell to v0.8.7
Add commands to move directionally between panes
data.body:
I originally implemented this as a package in https://github.com/atom/house-of-pane/pull/1, but following @nathansobo's [suggestion](https://github.com/atom/house-of-pane/pull/1#issuecomment-32731663), I'm opening this PR as an attempt to bake that package's functionality directly into [atom/atom](https://github.com/atom/atom).

---

Currently, Atom lets you switch focus to the **next** or **previous** pane.

![default-commands](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2988/1945935/64dc0f20-7fdf-11e3-8646-6375aada1d20.png)

When I find myself making the most of split panes (especially on a large display), I often want to be able to quickly move directionally to another pane. I want to tell Atom to move :arrow_up:, or :arrow_down:, or :arrow_left:, or :arrow_right:.

![new-commands](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2988/2005298/c059e814-86dc-11e3-8b4f-f3892a1b8fb7.png)

Kinda like this:

![house-of-pane-demo](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2988/1945880/3ac8c680-7fdd-11e3-8813-1d11c1833927.gif)

This PR is an attempt to provide those commands. As always, I'd appreciate any and all feedback!

data.title: Continuing to see a lot of files show up in project search after I've renamed or deleted them. Makes
data.body:
Continuing to see a lot of files show up in project search after I've renamed or deleted them. Makes search pretty hard to use for manual refactoring.

data.title: A comprehensive structure for our documentation
data.body:
I'm trying to get the skeleton in place for a comprehensive and overarching structure for our documentation. I'm thinking the docs will have three major sections that cross link with each other:
- **User's Manual:** This covers things a user might be interested in even if they don't want to script.
- **Developer's Manual:** This will be a high-level overview of various subsystems and concepts in Atom that's a bit higher level than the API docs. It's still fundamentally a reference.
- **Tutorials:** Take the key concepts from the developer's manual, break them into concrete examples, and sequence them in an easy-to-follow way. I'm thinking these can be based around explaining how to build one or more of our core packages.
- **API Reference:** This is the docs generated from our source comments.

I'd like to create empty files for any documentation we have missing, maybe just with the headings in place. Then we can gradually add detail to the sketch.

data.title: Allow rebinding keys that are bound to application menu items
data.body:
It appears that you cannot specify custom key bindings for items that appear in the application menu. I ran into the following issue while working on atom/tree-view#34; do the following to reproduce:
1. Clone [BinaryMuse/tree-view](https://github.com/BinaryMuse/tree-view) into `~/.atom/dev/packages/tree-view` and switch to the `bt-copy-paths` branch.
2. Fire up Atom with `atom -d` and, with a file open and focus in the editor, press `ctrl-C`. Notice that the path of the file has been copied into the clipboard by `editor:copy-path`.
3. Focus the tree view and select a different entry without changing the open file. With the tree view focused, press `ctrl-C`. Notice that the clipboard still contains the path to the currently open file, even though the `bkt-copy-paths` branch specifies that `ctrl-C` for `.tree-view` should execute `tree-view:copy-full-path`.

This happens because `ApplicationMenu` determines the specific command to execute when the menu item is clicked, without consulting the keymap specificity rules; this seems necessary for commands that are handled by `AtomApplication`.

This pull request introduces a change that sends the _keystroke_ to `WindowEventHandler`, instead of the command, in the case where `AtomApplication` does not handle the command itself.

Specs pass and things appear to work, but I'm not sure of the wider repercussions of this change, and would love to get some eyes on it. For one thing, since menu commands may now trigger different commands based on specificity, there may be a disconnect between what the menu item says and what it actually does. (This is okay for my example, where `ctrl-C` is bound to "Copy Path" in the menu, which makes sense in the new tree view context, but a user could easily rebind commands so that they no longer make sense--but maybe we don't care.)

data.body: These should be required by packages via a dependency in the `package.json` instead of requiring out of atom's core.

data.title: Remove some packages from core build.
data.body:
I think we should keep the default package list simple. Mainly for three reasons.
1. It gives people a reason to check out the package store and download packages.
2. It keeps the menu and command palette UI uncluttered.
3. There is a speed cost to loading extra packages.

data.title: Should closing the last tab in a pane make it go away?
data.body:
![2014-01-24 at 11 45 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/2000128/f601c68a-8551-11e3-9ae4-dcba5edd5fb1.png)

Just closed a tab in a pane, and got into this state, where a pane is open, but a few things are really unclear:
- Is there a way to close this empty pane?
- Is there a way to "select" it to open something else in it?
- Is this definitely a pane still, and not a visual glitch with the remaining pane not being resized?

I feel like closing any panes with zero tabs in them might be a way to clarify many of these limbo-state feelings.

data.title: Right-clicking on a line in search results will show a context menu, but it also navigates to the
data.body:
Right-clicking on a line in search results will show a context menu, but it also navigates to the search result. I wasn't trying to leave the results, I was trying to figure out how to collapse some of them.

data.title: Fix grunt install on Windows
data.body: This PR uses node-runas to install Atom to `%PROGRAMFILES%\Atom` with administrator privilege, and also creates a desktop shortcut to `atom.exe`.

data.title: Load ~/.atom/snippets.cson instead of ~/.atom/snippets/*
data.body: Matches the new pattern of having a single file in the `~/.atom` dir for these things that was previously done for keymaps.

data.title: Rename ~/.atom/user.css to ~/.atom/styles.css
data.body: Matches the naming scheme of the `keymap.cson` and `config.cson` files that are also in that folder.

data.title: Detecting file type from shebangs doesn't work if there's a space
data.body:
I saw that [work has been done on this previously](https://github.com/atom/atom/commit/83329567b9bad42a7b637b295706e51e56683154), but I've spotted that this isn't catching files that have a space in their shebang line, e.g.:

```
#! /usr/bin/env ruby
```

It's valid to write a shebang with a space before the command and they do work, so I guess it'll be a common enough case to cater for.

data.title: "Invalid regular expression" errors are not caught when searching
data.body:
I accidentally left the "Use Regex" option for "Find in Project" on and searched for a string that resulted in an invalid regular expression, and the resulting exception bubbled to the top of the stack:

```
Uncaught SyntaxError: Invalid regular expression: /.run (DsEvent/: Unterminated group - results-model.coffee:180
```

I'd be happy to address this, but I'm not sure what the desired end behavior is.

data.title: Add View suffix to Gutter & SelectList
data.body: These are the only two public classes that extend `View` but don't end in `View`
